results.title: Looking at lobsters
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Describes the life cycle of the rock lobster and shows its remarkable moulting behaviour. Notes the work of marine biologists from the CSIRO and WA Department of Fisheries in learning of the factors controlling its population levels, which are crucial to the maintenance of exports.

results.title: Leucaena: forage for the north
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Examines research by CSIRO’s Division of Tropical Crops and Pastures into leucaena, a legume native to Mexico, and its application to beef production in Northern Australia.

results.title: Landscapes from space
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Landsat data being processed by CSIRO are revealing a new picture of mineral areas, the environment, agriculture and land use planning in Western Australia.

results.title: In a nutshell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Australian gum trees are of considerable economic importance in various parts of the world. This demand is met by providing gum seeds to the countries that want our nuts.

results.title: Fire can be a friend
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Fire is a natural part of the Australian environment. Fire has been such a dominant factor that many native plants are adapted to periodic burning. Due to the supression of natural fires many square kilometres are being choked by a dense sea of invading shrubs.

results.title: Finding the balance: Arnhem Land
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Researchers have found that the Alligator Rivers region in Arnhem Land has the richest assortment of wilflife of any comparable area known in Australia. This film documents the scientists that piece together a comprehensive picture of the fauna in this area.

results.title: Fighting fire with fire
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Focuses on the research CSIRO have undertaken to understand wind, the most complex of environmental factors associated with bushfires. Sometimes exceeding 150 kilometres an hour, these winds can uproot huge trees, throwing them about like matches.

results.title: Csironet
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Today computers have many more applications outside science than in it. The result has been another information revolution. CSIRONET is CSIRO’s nationwide computer network, linking remote units to the Cyber 76, the most powerful computer in the southern hemisphere. This film shows some applications of the computer and the network.
